subject: Re: [K5science] RE: Should I purchase a microscope slide making kit?
msgSnippet: I am not a fan of kits. This may be a bias, but I find that they have stuff you will never use, not enough of what you do use, and other deficiencies. Low cost
messageBody:
I am not a fan of kits. This may be a bias, but I find that they have stuff you will never use, not enough of what you do use, and other deficiencies. Low cost kits have very inferior quality stuff. This goes for the kits you cite.

What (and really all) you need for making slides, at least at the beginning level, are:

 A box of slides and cover glasses. (Among other supply companies, Google: Carolina Biological/ and go slides cover glasses)

A pipet (Any medicine dropper type of pipet will do, but you may find these at Carolina Biological as well) 

An "X-acto" knife (You can get one of these at almost any department or hobby store.)

One or two teasing needles (toothpicks work perfectly well)

Forceps with fine tips (a regular drugstore item)

A box of tissue paper (Nothing special, just regular facial tissues)

The total purchase price of these items will be under 30 dollars and will serve you well.

For instruction in making slides, Google: making microscope slides video/.

With these things, I think kids 8 and up who have reasonable manual dexterity,  with practice, will be able to make good slides. Only be sure that you give your kids due instruction in handling/using the X-acto knife safely. They are literally razor sharp. 

Please let us know how it goes.

Bernie Nebel

 I was going to buy slides for the microscope when I saw slide preparation kits. Should I buy any? If so, should I buy a toy kit with plastic knives($17) or a basic professional kit with glass petri dishes, test tubes with holders and surgical knife etc($99)? In construction, it's almost impossible to get a good quality job done without the right tools. I am adopting this philosophy in buying stuff for our home lab. But since our kids are so young at 8 and 11, I am wondering if buying an advanced kit is premature. What has your experience been?
